utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Hi, everyone. Data stories number 18. And. Hey, Morris. And believe it or not, we have been doing this. This thing for one year now.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: One year. Amazing.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Amazing. Amazing. So exactly one year ago, we published our first episode.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Who knew one year could feel so long?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. I cannot believe it. I mean, it's so fast.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, it's crazy.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: But, you know, a lot happened in between as well, so. Yeah, it's both fast and slow.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: You know, it's an episode, so we didn't quite live up to the two weeks rhythm. Yeah, but, you know, we need to take vacations too, right?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: We are almost there.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I mean, I think it's all that were really long. So.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: So, let me see. We published two in February, 2 in March, 1 in April, and May was lazy. One in June. No, two in June, 1 in July, 1 in August. You can see nothing in May.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Did we like skip May or what?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: No, one in May. 2 in June, 2 in June, 1 in July, 1 in August. You can see the summer effect. Yeah, but, I mean, it's good. It's good.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: You know, three weeks worked out fine, I think. I mean, two weeks is a bit tough on everybody. I mean, who can stand to listen to us every two weeks?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, that would be boring.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: That's the other thing. We have to think of our listeners as well.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. And that's the first time after a long time that it's me and you and it's only audio.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, probably like for a year.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Maybe.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I think we started out like that and then we. Yeah, we just had so many guests. I mean, that was great, too. But it's also nice to do a one on one episode again.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I still believe that our first episode has the best title ever. I think you came up with this.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Title, exuberant animated data kitsch. Yeah. We should have called the whole podcast like that. I think we had the idea too late.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah. We should keep inventing titles like this. That's more. That's fun.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: This might be a good plan for the next year to have more funnier titles.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Compare this with Immortal with Stefan and studio NAND.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, but, you know, the second one was already also quite descriptive. It was called visualization contests, marathons, challenges, awards, etcetera. I mean, that's not that inventive.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: So our highlight was the first episode. After that, things went clearly downhill.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Well, you can actually see this from the stats.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, that's true. No, actually, our most popular episode was episode number five with Andy Kirk.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Andy Kirk. Andy. Wow.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Andy. Hi, Andy. Thanks for sending some of your glamour over here for at least one episode.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: But we actually had Andy more than once.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, so had.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: But we had the peak only once. So we have to check whether it depends on Andy. On whether it depends on. Maybe it depends on what we discussed there. So maybe it's not the Andy effect.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. So you mean it's not a scientific experiment we did.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, it's true. So anyway, in case it's not clear, what we are gonna do in this episode is basically going through the list of past episodes and comment on that. It's gonna be a kind of carousel. We didn't come up with any better idea than this for the data stories birthday.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Or for Valentine's Day.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Or for Valentine. I think it's really nice. So I never realized that actually we started on Valentine's Day.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, that's. That's so funny. I mean, didn't we have better things to do? Honestly, no, but I think we didn't record the first episode on Valentine's Day, but we published it there to our defense. But now that's today we're sitting there.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: That's possible.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: We should take care of our wives.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Rather than record podcasts.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Anyway. Okay, let's start with episode one. What did we talk about in episode one? I don't even remember.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I think we talked about all these. You know, I was ranting a bit about these particle based animations of world maps and things flying around and trails, glow effects, this type of thing.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, I think that's still totally unsolved. Right?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. But I think. I think it was sort of a fashion that a bit that went away in a way. I have the feeling. So I wouldn't rant the same way now.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. But, you know, I'm still totally fascinated by animation. I think it's a. It's a. It's an aspect of visualization that is not well understood well enough yet.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I mean, animation fascinates me a lot. And I think. I think we have to. We have to investigate much closer what we can do well with animation. Because I'm convinced. Convinced that there are things we can do really well with animation.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Sure. I mean, it's been done. And I think what also turned out over the years that these short animated explanatory clips can work quite well. So the New York Times did quite a few of these. And my sense is also that with increased mobile use and, like, in between use of visualization, that these short animations, they can be quite effective. That's right.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. But I wasn't ranting so much about these sort of narrative things, but more the ones where you have a development over time and then you just have a lot of particles moving.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: You're really fascinated while you watch it. And afterwards it's all gone. You know, it's like I said that recently about that Twitter visualization, you know, the tweet ping thing. So you watch. You watch it, it's like crazy. And you think you're consuming so much of interesting stuff, and then you close the browser tab and nothing's left. You know, it's like it evaporates, basically. And I think that's still true to some degree.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I agree. I agree. I totally agree.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Anyways, number two, we were ranting about, or you were ranting about marathons and challenges and awards.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: It's fun because looking back, that was a bit exaggerated, I think at the time.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: There were quite a few crappy awards or also dubious ones, you know, that had dubious terms of conditions until when.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: You decided to participate to some of those. Right.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. Afterwards, things somehow got a bit better and we had the EQ Librium, which really upset you. I mean, your pulse always went up, like 20 points when you were talking about that.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Maybe that was a bit too harsh, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah. And then this, this robbery, you know, that spotlight of profitability didn't win.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, that was crazy. And I still think that was a fantastic piece of visualization.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: And you know what, Christina, she won more prizes. I think she won a couple of challenges in the meantime, at least the OECD one with a piece that I didn't understand but which looked good, really. But I didn't get it quite fully, honestly. And another second place. And actually, I've been working with her in the meantime, so.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Oh, cool.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah, yeah. So I did a little project right before Christmas with her for World Economic forum, and we might do another one.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: So is there anything public yet?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, we could link to it. I mean, it's not spectacular. It's just solid infographics for a print report, but I can dig it out.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Good, good. So do you think that during this year something changed in the way these contests and prizes are organized and given.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: You're setting me up here.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: No, I'm serious. I mean, in a way, I've seen less of them.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I mean, I was really impressed by the visualizing marathon this year. There were like really over a thousand students worldwide taking part, and the entries were really great.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I mean, yeah, I agree. I agree.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: So I was really impressed there. And I felt there were much less of these pointless designers. Something funny, contests. And we can do whatever we want with it. And you get like, I don't know, some hideous prize. So I haven't seen these anymore. So I think the issue is sorted.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Good. Done.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, mission accomplished. Congratulations.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Just one episode.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Well done and well done.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: It was worth it.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Super.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Enrico saved the world again against prices and contests.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Okay, number three.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Number three. How do you evaluate visualization? This looks academic to me. Maybe I was proposing this.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, I think it was a boring episode.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: That's where we have a huge valley in the trends. Right?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: There were a few good. And now that I read the recap, there were a few good points there, I think.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. And we've been organizing our, what did I want to say, our workshop this week last year, the belief workshop, that is about evaluation, visualization. And we organize this every two years and it was quite successful again. So this is such a nice, never ending topic. You can always add something new there. So. Yeah, and I think it's important, but.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Do you feel, is there progress in that area? Like, do people use different methods now or do people look at different things in the evaluations?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I think it's a big topic. I think we've been, at least from the academic point of view, we have improved a lot. A lot. I mean, now we are in the situation where for certain kind of contributions, if you don't have a proper evaluation, it's very hard for someone to get accepted. So I think that's already some kind of progress. What I haven't seen lately is more innovation in the way visualization is evaluated. I would like to see more innovation. So basically the most solid stuff is still running a controlled experiment, which is fine, but I think we should try to do something else. Oh, by the way, have you seen this highly criticized evaluation doing brain scan?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: No, I missed to read that. I had it in my list and totally forgot to read it. What was it about?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: So, long story short, my friend Rem Ko Chang from Tufte University, he ran this very nice experiment comparing the infamous bar chart versus versus pie chart. And they pretended to evaluate this according to, by using a special brain scan technique. I don't remember exactly the name of this technique, but basically I think it's MRI, probably. Yeah, exactly, something like that. And they claim that this technique is able to measure the workload, the human workload, when they are performing some tasks. And one of the findings is that basically in terms of workload, there's no difference between bar chart and pie charts. But even more interesting than that is the fact. I think that's the most interesting thing, is that people behave differently. So some people have a higher workload with pie charts, and some other people have a higher workload with. What did I say? I don't remember the other one. Okay.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: But this was heavily, heavily criticized.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Like a really conclusive experience.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: It's not conclusive. Yeah, I think that. So I didn't read the paper yet, and I didn't fully read the criticism from Stephen Few. But my feeling is that what is. So the main focus of this research is more trying to see whether it's feasible to evaluate visualization through this method.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, that's really interesting.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. Rather than saying anything conclusive on pie chart versus bar charts. Right.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. So I think that's the problem is with such a result, it could also mean they're measuring the wrong thing or they're measuring nothing at all. You know, it's very hard to.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Absolutely, absolutely. But I've been briefly talking with Remko a few days ago, and what he told me is that basically, one of his co authors is really a leader in the. In this field. He's a guy who's been studying.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. Tufts is very well known in the cognitive science area, so they're really top notch. So, yeah, I'm pretty sure they know what they're doing.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: So, basically, this is what I'm saying about evaluation. I would like to see much more, many more of this kind of studies where people really try to do innovative stuff.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Mm hmm. Measure the pulse of Stephen Few when he sees a surface. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I mean.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Adrenaline levels.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I mean, honestly, I think. I think he's super smart, but the way he writes this kind of rants, I still have some problems with it. I mean, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, sure. He's just rude. I mean, sorry, but I really liked his slow, slow data article. I was.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Sure, sure. Me too.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: That was what was really good. So I think he's a smart guy. He's just being rude.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: He likes to provoke, I guess.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. Yeah, makes sense.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Anyways, we're diverging here. How do you say that?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: No, how do you say diverging? Yeah, but diverging to episode four. Four. I think that was really successful.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Malofiej. Yeah, that was Malofiej. We were so, you know, Andy and I, we were just coming back from Malofiej was still totally under the influence of that crazy event, and.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: And it was a lot of. I mean, we went through all of the people. I mean, that was a lot of material, basically.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I think Malofiej was one of the biggest events in 2012. Right?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. For me, it was really important. And, I mean, I think for all who were involved with it, it was like Andy and Andrew and so on. It was really a big eye opener. Also, Robert, I think also for Robert, it changed his view on the whole infographics scene quite a bit as well, and.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Was fantastic.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. And I think it's the first time that people from, I don't know, kind of like data journalism infographics meet with people that come more from the infobird side. Right?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. I mean, or at least. Yeah, it's been more of that. I think they started to do that. Yeah. But you're right. I mean, also Alberto, I think there was much Alberto Cairo's initiative, and I think he. He said that was really also. Yeah. The years before, it wasn't like that. And that he wanted to bridge these worlds a bit. And I think he was quite successful. If you think, like, how it played out later, you know, like how the year played out, I think there were stronger bonds than between the scenes, so.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: So do you think they're gonna. They're gonna organize the same thing this year?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah, it's every year. I mean, it's. It was called Malofiej 20 because it was the 20th edition, basically.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: No, but I mean, do you think we are gonna have, again, nice mix of people.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, definitely. I mean, I know who's going. So there's Jan Willem Tulp.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Oh, great.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: There is Fernanda Viegas. There is Stephanie Posavec.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Oh, cool.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, yeah. So they continue to invite the good, the tradition. No, no, I love that. It's great.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Okay. Lots of these people was in our guest list. Right?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Exactly. You heard it here first.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: What else? What else? What did we do then?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Another one with Andy. Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Another one with Andy. Oh, shame on us.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: And that's the most, as you said, the most successful one. How to learn data visualization with Andy Kirk.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Okay.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: That was really good. I mean, he told us a lot about how he does his courses and know what he thinks is most important. I think a lot of that stuff is really still valid.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. You know, from my point of view, this is still one of the biggest challenges we have in our field because we've been focusing on. So from our side, the academic side, we've been focusing on doing research. Right. Practitioners have been focusing on doing their stuff. Right. On producing stuff. And very, very few people focused on the problem of teaching other people how to do visualization correctly. And at the same time, I think that's one of the biggest needs we have right now. And for the first time, we have very nice sources, very nice books, very nice people willing to teach. I mean, that's another big trend this year from my point of view. So we have, Andy has been teaching all around the world. We have Alberto Cairo, who's been, who's been teaching through his. What's the name of his course? I don't remember.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. He does it online.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Large scale MOOC. Yeah, MOOC. And what else? I think Katie Burner is now. Katie Burner is doing the same thing now. And that's big. I think that's big.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Everybody wants to learn it. I think we should stop that teaching thing. I think it's going to be too many people.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: It's getting too crowded on that beach here. Stop doing that.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I agree. I agree. And right now I'm teaching, which is.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I'm teaching, too. I just had yesterday my first lecture in a new course, so I should shut up. It's fun. Teaching is just, it's a very rewarding thing. You know, I always say I'm a bad teacher, and I am, actually. I know that. But. But still, I enjoy it. It's a bit like guitar playing for me.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I'm really bad at it, too, but I sort of like it.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. And look, for my course, as I was saying, as I was telling to you before starting the episode in my course, I'm using the draft of Tamara Munzner's book. And for me, it's.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Wow.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: This book is the book I've always dreamed of. I mean, it's kind of like a perfect summary of visualization design. And it's the kind of book that I never. That, I mean, we have, we have quite a good number of visualization related books in our bookshelves, but I never had a book like this before. One book that is totally focused on the design techniques and principles of information visualization and the fact that she's breaking down the problems in very nice, very well organized set of tools and problems.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: So, yeah, she's super precise and super clear, simply. I enjoy that about her. She has a clear head.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah, I think, I mean, I don't know exactly when this book is gonna be published, but I think for me, that's gonna be a big event because this book is different from every other book I've seen so far.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, sounds good. There's a draft online so we can link to it.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: There's a draft online. Yeah, we should.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, we should. Definitely. Okay.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Episode six. Episode six on food. How could we call an episode on food?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: That was a fun one. I remember I was pretty hungover, or was I ill or so. But I was in Manchester when we recorded it, and I was just sitting in my apartment bed. I sort of remember that.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: And that was a nice one.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: That was a nice one.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: In fact, you know, I talked about the data cuisine idea in this episode, and in September we made it happen.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: So, yeah, visualizing food is cool. We should actually keep doing this thing and maybe doing on something else. Right.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I like that. Yeah. Just to talk about specific topics, you know, outside of visualization, you know, from visualization angle. I really liked it. Yeah. So maybe we shouldn't have so many data vis guys on the show, but maybe experts from other areas. Could be interesting.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Could be interesting.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: I have a philosopher, biologist.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. Yeah. Well, actually, there's a lot of vis in biology. It's crazy.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, sure.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Did you ever participate to any of these conferences? I did. It's crazy because you have all in a sudden you realize that there are thousands and thousands of biologists who do visualization by themselves, and they are pretty advanced. Anyway, episode seven, color caller with Gregor ice. That was a great one. That was a great one. I mean, I learned something during, during that episode. And Gregory.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah. Probably, like, information density wise, that's the most informative one we've ever done, I think.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Yeah. And I still think that if you want to learn visualization, you should listen to this episode. It's part of it, right?

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: You get so much information about how to use color properly and all the nuances of using color properly that it's. It's really, really good.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: Episode eight, the first interview, I think the first real interview, in a sense.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yes. I mean, with Andy and Gregor, it's been more like. I don't know. Yeah. Like a conversation. And with Jeff, it was much more like, okay, we have Jeff on the show. What do we ask him?

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini
utterances.text: I think we have a little peak here in our.

utterances.speaker: Moritz Stefaner
utterances.text: Yeah, that was a very popular one as well.

utterances.speaker: Enrico Bertini

chapters.summary: Exactly one year ago, we published our first episode. Who knew one year could feel so long? We should keep inventing titles like this. Most popular episode was episode number five with Andy Kirk.
chapters.headline: One year ago, we published our first episode

chapters.summary: This episode will go through the list of past episodes and comment on that. I never realized that actually we started on Valentine's Day. That's possible. We should take care of our wives. Rather than record podcasts.
chapters.headline: Data stories started on Valentine's Day. So I never realized that actually we started on

chapters.summary: I'm still totally fascinated by animation. It's an aspect of visualization that is not well understood well enough yet. We have to investigate much closer what we can do well with animation. With increased mobile use, these short animations can be quite effective.
chapters.headline: I'm still totally fascinated by animation. I think we have to investigate more

chapters.summary: There were quite a few crappy awards or also dubious ones. And I still think that was a fantastic piece of visualization. And actually, I've been working with her in the meantime. So I did a little project right before Christmas with her for World Economic forum, and we might do another one.
chapters.gist: A Taste of the EQ Librium
chapters.headline: You ranted about marathons and challenges and awards at EQ Librium

chapters.summary: I was really impressed by the visualizing marathon this year. And I felt there were much less of these pointless designers. So I think the issue is sorted. Just one episode. Well done and well done.
chapters.headline: So do you think that during this year something changed in the way contests are organized

chapters.summary: How do you evaluate visualization? This looks academic to me. Do you feel, is there progress in that area? What I haven't seen lately is more innovation in the way visualization is evaluated.
chapters.headline: How do you evaluate visualization? This looks academic to me

chapters.summary: I think Malofiej was one of the biggest events in 2012. It's the first time that people from data journalism infographics meet with people that come more from the infobird side. Do you think the same thing will happen this year?
chapters.headline: Malofiej was one of the biggest infographics events in 2012

chapters.summary: How to learn data visualization with Andy Kirk. For the first time, we have very nice sources and very nice books, very nice people willing to teach. I think we should stop that teaching thing. It's going to be too many people.
